qas.question: Along with Morocco and Tunisia, in what country are the Darijas spoken?
What is the liturgical language of Islam?
In what language is the Qur'an written?
What does the term Dariajs refer to?
What is the dominant religion of North Africa?
Where are the Darijas considered the same as other Arabic dialects?
Which countries tend to give preference to the Darijas?
In which language is the Darijas written?
What is the language of folk-tale books?
Which language is the liturgical language of social media?

context: In <b5_0>Tunisia, <a0_0>Algeria<a0_0/>, and Morocco<b5_0/>, the Darijas (<a3_0>spoken North African languages<a3_0/>) are sometimes considered more different from other Arabic dialects. Officially, <b6_0>North African countries<b6_0/> prefer to give preference to the <a1_0><a2_0>Literary Arabic<a2_0/><a1_0/> and conduct much of their political and religious life in it (adherence to <a4_0>Islam<a4_0/>), and refrain from declaring each country's specific variety to be a separate language, because <b7_0><b8_0><b9_0>Literary Arabic<b9_0/><b8_0/><b7_0/> is the liturgical language of Islam and the language of the Islamic sacred book, the Qur'an. Although, especially since the 1960s, the Darijas are occupying an increasing use and influence in the cultural life of these countries. Examples of cultural elements where Darijas' use became dominant include: theatre, film, music, television, advertisement, social media, folk-tale books and companies' names.
